To fathom the profound and measure the ultimate is especially difficult when facing the void—only then does one realize that the wondrous numinous observation of the Dao holds a thousandfold path. When the feet are whole and sound, and the mysterious heart stands firm as a wall, one then knows the fortune of seeking the steadfastness of the heart and the wholeness of the feet. Thus, many follow its lineage, but few reach its extremity.

Yet with an unyielding heart, one ascends to the jade purity of the True One’s resonance; with an unobstructed journey, one seeks the firmness of ultimate life. Only then may one attain jade radiance to equal illumination and ultimately receive the extended countenance of the Thearch. To wander aimlessly is to hope for nothing after ten thousand attempts; to focus single-mindedly is to have hope fulfilled ten thousandfold.

Those who cling to external passions and seek refuge in mere existence, upon hearing the Dao, crawl forward on their knees—yet when the Dao remains silent, all vanish. Facing the mountains, their legs grow numb with cold; crossing the rivers, their blood surges in waves. Their five limbs assail one another over unfallen valleys, their whole body trembles on the brink of life and death. Such efforts merely exhaust their allotted years in toil, serving as mere adornments to fame and reputation. All this arises from a scattered, unfocused heart and a drifting, unstable nature. Day by day, their distractions grow, yet they remain unaware, corrupting rectitude and losing resolve, wandering lost in the forest of the Dao’s dream—how could they be worthy of the supreme Way?

Now I shall reveal to you the transcendent arts of the numinous truth, the methods of celestial immortality, the grand esoteric essentials, and the *Scripture of Eternal Preservation in the Upper Realm*. If you wish to ascend to heaven in broad daylight, journey north to the Jade Thearch, spur the dragon to ride the light, and dwell in the palaces of the Upper Clarity; if you wish to hurl the jade wheels, turn the five celestial bodies, merge with the sun to radiate brilliance, and enter the moon to pierce its clarity—you must obtain the *Hidden Writ of Jade Clarity* and wear the divine *Golden Tiger Talisman*.

With the *Crimson Text of Yu Yi*, you may summon the sun to rise together; with the *Yellow Chapters of Jie Lin*, you may dwell with the moon. The *Cavernous True Scripture* allows you to roam with the five celestial bodies; the *Great Cavern True Scripture* scatters enmity across seven generations. Its thirty-nine chapters enable seven generations of ancestors to ascend as immortals. The *Eight Ways of the Yellow Elder* and the *Nine Numinous Writs*—the *Purple Text of the Ascending Numinous Writ* refines and restrains the hun and po; the *Golden Watchtower* records the annals. The *Treasure Registers of the Five Elders*, the *Hundred Mushrooms of the Jade Court*, the *Essence Medicines of the Upper Clarity*, and the *Excerpts from the Jade Clarity Scripture of Wisdom*—these declare:

Six pure blossoms flourish, the eight-cornered radiance of the mysterious light; the seeds of wind and cloud, the jade threshold of the Thearch’s terrace; golden petals of the *jia* blossom, the vast yellow trees of heaven; the jade buds of Changcheng, the fire-jade of Mount Ye; the singing of the phoenix grove in Lu, the jade wine of the Western Jasper; the purple honey of the Central Hua, the green mounds of the Northern Ling; the golden marrow of the Crimson Ford, the moon’s essence and sun’s longevity; the *lang* seeds of the Vermilion River, the patterned gourds of Penglai; the seven stems of Zhuo Water, the lightning willows of collapsing peaks; plucking the green onions of the Northern Xuan Guo, sipping the crimson honey of cloud and water; the bones of the Night Ox, the yellow lacquer of the divine *wu*; the *ling* melons of Kongtong, one fruit every four kalpas; the gall of the *lin* in the Dark City, the midnight sun of Flame Mountain; gathering the cinnabar mulberries of Fusang above, harvesting the standing algae of the Long Abyss below; harmonizing the flying jade of the nine transformations above, swallowing the rosy treasures of the Azure Mystery below; the Great Void’s linked rings, the embrace of the Plain Girl; the purple *qiu* lads, the nine-colored phoenix brains; the hidden mushrooms of the Great Ultimate, the crimson trees of the sun’s path; the rainbow plums of the Supreme, the great herbs of the Celestial Han; the giant pearls of the Southern Palace, the *fu* elders of the Western Land; the three-beamed dragon flowers, sought by the numinous consorts—those who consume these will age only after heaven itself.

This is what the Jade Clarity consumes, what the Supreme treasures—enabling one to ascend and soar through the luminous clouds, divide the morning into myriad paths, guard and stabilize the imperial essence, and infuse the nine brains with morning light.

Yet this Way is vast and supremely subtle, its numinous radiance distant—it is not something those who consume blood and flesh may fully comprehend. Merely hearing its mysterious tones scatters the turbid; listening to its wind and qi dispels the impure. Above, it can float beyond the grand primordial; below, it can dispel demons and cure illnesses. Without a resonant root of virtue, who could merge with its numinous ease?

Thus, the highest method dispels demons by ordering qi through the myriad connections; the names of the supreme true medicines nurture the spirit and expel evil. Truly, these words are trustworthy.

Next are the *Mysterious Mushrooms of the Upper Clarity* and the *Nine Seasons of the Supreme*. There are the *Eight Radiant Great Harmonies*, the *Mottled Dragon’s Black Embryo*, the *Patterned Tiger’s White Foam* from the Western Mound; the *Seven Dark Flying Nodes*, the *Nine-Aperture Jade Pearls*; the *Cloud Nectar* and *Jasper Wine*, the *Lang Yu* of the *Xuan Garden*; the *White Glue of Mount Zhong*, the *Golden Bloom of Green Spread*; the *Stone Brains of Langfeng*, the *Coral of the Black River*; the *White Phoenix of Mount Meng*, the *Jade Veins of the Numinous Mound*; the *Golden Blood of the Azure Luan*, the *Vermilion Leaves of Dongying*; the *Nine-Node Intertwined*, the *Purple Hemp of the Great Tenuity*; the *Jade Fruits of Qionghua*, the *Whale Pearls of Flowing Abyss*; the *Crimson Walls of the Red River*—drawing from the *Great Ultimate’s Well* at the center, plucking the *Crimson Veins of Wen Zhu*; the *Divine Peaches of the Cloud Court*, the *Flat Sparrows of Kun Garden*; the *Sun Grass of Night Essence*, the *Green Reed of Azure Ford*; the *Fragrant Altars of the True Palace*, the *Three Canopies of the Dark Capital*—wearing the light of the *Jade Lads* on the left, drawing the qi of the *Jade Maidens* on the right; summoning the *Divine Origin* above, drinking the *Mysterious Ripple* below; grasping the *Jade Essence of the Orchid Garden* above, plucking the *Purple [Herb]* of the Round Mound below; the *Spiritual Clams of White Water*, the *Red Scallions of the Eight Heavens*—one fruit every ten thousand years, nine ranks of flowing light. Those who consume these will depart after heaven itself.

This is what the Heavenly Thearch consumes, what the Supreme treasures—unheard of in the Great Ultimate, unattainable by the middle immortals. Reciting its chapters grants eternal life in the extraordinary currents; chanting its names can cure illnesses and sever demons. For the *Scriptures of Wisdom* dispel demons, their excerpts distilled from wondrous images; the *Numinous Mushrooms* and *Supreme Medicines*, the *Pure Songs of the True Thearch*, are but rough stimulants within the gaze of the Dao.

Wearing talismans and bearing the true, reciting the *Nine Simplicities*—this may suffice to fathom the natures of the myriad demons. Embracing the origin and receiving qi, studying the *Jade Mystery* at dawn—one must guard it beyond ten thousand kalpas.

The four *hun* and nine *po* thus fulfill their functions within the body—using them brings joy beyond measure.

Next are the grades of the Great Ultimate, the four true constant treasures: the *Nine Stones Refined in Smoke*, the *Elixir Liquid and Jade Nourishment*; the *Flowing Pearls of Xunshou*, the *Jasper Essence of Linhua*; the *Golden Liquid of the Cinnabar Furnace*, the *Purple Flowers and Rainbow Blossoms*; the *Nine Transformations of the Great Clarity*, the *Nectar of the Five Clouds*; the *Mysterious Frost and Descending Snow*, the *Leaping Three Yellows*; the *White Incense of Dongying*, the *Green Coins of Canglang*; the *Surplus Grain of High Mounds*, the *Flying Fields of Accumulated Stones*; the *Returning Elixir of the Great Void*, the *Mysterious Firmness of Taiqin*; the *Flowing Herbs of Eternal Light*, the *Flying Thousands of Cloud Lads*—these too enable one to ascend lightly and soar into the ethereal darkness.

chunks.original_text: 此天仙之所服，飞神之所研，非陆游之所闻，山客之所见也。 又当知九化十变隐地八术，然后乃能广游玄空，倒步天阿，乘云驾龙，凌腾无方矣。 其次又有三十六芝，飞炉炼烟，阳水月华，五石之腴，填生五藏，炼貌易躯，及瑰葩云屑，金粉玉柔，亦能延年益寿，可至万岁也。 其次又有玄水云华之浆，五黄郁灵中精，千石琼饮，众青朱英，白车飞节之实，流马紫木之黄，一服立使人长算千纪，日服日延，年随药进，命与药迁，亦无穷之灵物，不死之奇方也。 夫长算千纪，时谓服但一刀圭而已耳。 毕其下药，先有松□阴脂，山姜伏神，昌蒲门冬，巨胜黄精，菊花苟杞，崖蜜茯苓，桃皮泽泻，葳甤黄连，升麻地黄，赤板朱英，云飞水桂，众物之精，其类繁多，略举一端，服之为能小益，不能永申，高可七百年，下可三四百岁，恐不辨长享，无期上升青天也。 亦能身生光泽，还白童颜，役使千神，得为地仙，陆行五岳，游浪名山，故不自辟其必死也。 又渐求上药，以自改新，则易为阶级之进，何必守故而不迁，取期限以役齿乎。 然此等道，宜柔弱温仁，至心一意，洁体清净，调和五藏，安形念景，存保百神，守魂炼魄，除秽荡滓，游心重玄，情无流华之欲，抱一独往，怀无婴尘之累，熏辛五辣，不近於口，肥滋血味，不经於肠，山居空处，不营外事，乃上可以耽玄存真，召神符灵，下可以饵食八石，呼吸液津也。 夫阴丹内御房中之术，黄道赤炁交接之益，七九朝精吐纳之要，六一回丹雌雄之法，虽获仙名，而上清不以比德，虽均致化，而太上不以为贵，此秽仙浊真，固不得阀乎玉闼矣。 且崄巇履冰，多见倒车之败，纵有全者，臭乱之地仙耳。 想访拟高范，不足絓意，而注营乎近，不及导引服炁之法，胎息闭心存念之术，幽神中篇，金匮隐旨，黄庭内外，太清守记，凡如此道，数千余事，皆流传俗间，兆所知闻，自中世以来，轩辕之后，以此诸道而登度者，人以岳积不可胜数。 此懃心至矣，守精笃矣，秉操坚矣，志向定矣，行此四德，余将为兆破魔升仙也。 至於不固之人，有为之者，或弥年历纪，不得其益，何也，或服引呼吸不得其理，或为他物所惑，将成而败，或暂得其益，遇疾则止，或师将告之，而不知别，或心不能专，精神纷错，或积罪作咎，以犯天忌，或虚增经方，以意损益，凡如此者，往往相寻，此皆浮华之人，傲秽之士，为有虚言，不可教也。 故使大道不匝於天下，真仙希游於世间，皆人之深责，非吾党之咎累矣。 夫诀在平淡无营，内视八道，数神垂魂，不苟不保，灰尘九魂，抱一游冥，五藏莫放，液炁玄凝，临死生而不畏，对奇怪而不倾，纵天形於空同，敛神和而守精。 於是大试於何而起，妖罔从何而生，金石不能比其大质，八流不能敌其渊停。 澄正之才，实由天生，亦可学而速获，亦可不求而成矣。 格而言之，仙非强可求，真非干可营，自无玄籍，自不得闻智慧之经； 自无玉书，终不见吾神金虎章； 自非懃慕飞仙，不得知太极上清。 揔而言之，分也，志也，精也，懃也，行阴德也，救灾厄也，慧穷困也，立仁功也。 都而统之，慈心以对万物，勿行凶心以向万生，道要之门户矣，获道之曲室也。

These are the substances consumed by the Heavenly Transcendents, the studies pursued by the soaring spirits—beyond the ken of wandering scholars or mountain recluses. One must further master the *Nine Transformations and Ten Changes*, the *Eight Hidden Earth Arts*, only then can one roam boundlessly through the Mysterious Void, stride backward along the Celestial River’s banks, ride clouds and mount dragons, soaring without limit.

Next are the *Thirty-Six Mushrooms*, the *Flying Furnace’s Refined Smoke*, the *Yang Water and Moon Essence*, the *Five Stones’ Richness*—which replenish the five viscera, refine the countenance, and transform the body. There are also the *Radiant Petals and Cloud Fragments*, the *Golden Powder and Jade Tenderness*, which can prolong life and extend years, granting longevity up to ten thousand years.

Further still are the *Mysterious Water and Cloud Essence Elixir*, the *Five Yellows’ Profound Spirit*, the *Thousand-Stone Jade Draft*, the *Multicolored Reds and Greens*, the *White Chariot’s Flying Nodes*, the *Flowing Steed’s Purple Wood Essence*—a single dose instantly extends one’s lifespan by a thousand epochs. Daily consumption steadily lengthens life, years advancing with the medicine, destiny shifting with the elixir. These are indeed inexhaustible numinous substances, wondrous formulas of deathlessness.

To extend life by a thousand epochs, it is said, requires but a single *daogui* of the medicine. Before refining the lower elixirs, one must first prepare *Pine Resin and Shade Fat*, *Mountain Ginger and Hidden Spirit*, *Sweetflag and Asparagus*, *Giant Sesame and Yellow Essence*, *Chrysanthemum and Wolfberry*, *Cliff Honey and Poria*, *Peach Bark and Alisma*, *Weirui and Coptis*, *Cimicifuga and Rehmannia*, *Red Plates and Vermilion Blossoms*, *Cloud-Soaring Water Cassia*, and the essences of countless other substances. Though these are myriad in kind, only a fraction is mentioned here. Consuming them yields modest benefits, not eternal extension—at best, seven hundred years; at least, three or four hundred. Yet without discerning the path to enduring enjoyment, one cannot ascend to the Azure Heavens. They may restore radiance to the body, return the complexion to youthful whiteness, command a thousand spirits, and attain the rank of Earth Transcendent—traversing the Five Peaks, wandering renowned mountains—thus avoiding the certainty of death.

Yet one should gradually seek higher medicines to renew oneself, for such advancement is but a step on the ladder. Why cling to the old and refuse change, binding oneself to temporal limits? These arts demand gentleness, warmth, benevolence, and wholehearted sincerity—purifying the body, harmonizing the five viscera, calming the form, visualizing the spirit, preserving the hundred spirits, guarding the hun and refining the po, dispelling filth and cleansing impurities. The mind roams the *Double Mystery*, free from the desires of fleeting splendor; embracing unity, one wanders alone, unburdened by the dust of the world. Pungent spices and five acrid flavors must not pass the lips; rich, bloody flavors must not enter the intestines. Dwelling in mountain solitude, one must not pursue worldly affairs—only then can one above delve into the profound and preserve the true, summon spirits and invoke numinous talismans, and below consume the *Eight Stones* and practice *liquid and saliva* absorption.

As for the *Yin Elixir’s Internal Chamber Arts*, the benefits of the *Yellow Way and Red Qi’s* union, the essentials of *Seven-Nine Refining Essence and Exhalation*, the methods of the *Six-One Returning Elixir’s* yin-yang fusion—though these may confer the name of immortality, the *Upper Clarity* does not equate them with virtue. Though they achieve transformation, the *Supreme* does not hold them in esteem. These are the *Impure Transcendents and Tainted Perfected*—they cannot pass through the Jade Portal.

Moreover, treading treacherous ice is perilous, often leading to ruin. Even those who survive remain but *Foul and Disorderly Earth Transcendents*. To aspire to lofty models is not worth attachment; to fixate on the near is to fall short of *guiding and absorbing qi*, the arts of *embryonic breathing and mind-sealing visualization*, the *Mysterious Spirit’s Central Scroll*, the *Golden Casket’s Hidden Principles*, the *Yellow Court’s Inner and Outer Scriptures*, and the *Great Clarity’s Guarding Records*. Such methods, numbering in the thousands, have all circulated among the common folk and are known to the masses. Since the middle ages, from the time of the Yellow Emperor onward, those who have ascended and transcended through these arts are as numerous as mountains—impossible to count.

Such dedication of the heart, such steadfastness in preserving essence, such firmness in upholding conduct, such resolve in purpose—possessing these four virtues, I shall help you shatter demons and ascend as a transcendent. Yet for those of unstable nature who practice these arts, even after years or decades, they may gain no benefit. Why? Some fail to grasp the principles of *guiding and absorbing breath*; others are misled by external distractions, succeeding only to fail. Some briefly gain benefits but cease at the onset of illness; others receive teachings from masters but cannot discern them. Some lack single-minded focus, their spirits scattered; others accumulate sins and offenses, violating heavenly taboos. Some arbitrarily alter scriptural formulas, adding or omitting at will. Such cases are common—these are frivolous, arrogant, and filthy individuals, given to empty words, beyond instruction.

Thus, the Great Dao does not spread throughout the world, and true transcendents rarely wander the earth—this is the deep fault of humanity, not the burden of our fellowship. The key lies in simplicity, free from scheming, inwardly observing the *Eight Paths*, counting the spirits and beckoning the hun, neither careless nor overprotective, reducing the *Nine Hun* to ashes, embracing unity and roaming the dark, the five viscera never straying, the *liquid and qi* mysteriously congealing. Facing death without fear, encountering the strange without faltering, releasing the celestial form into the empty vastness, gathering the spirit and harmonizing it to guard essence.

Then, from what does the great trial arise? From where do illusions emerge? No metal or stone can compare to its great substance; no eight streams can rival its profound stillness. Such clarity of talent is truly heaven-born—yet it may also be swiftly attained through learning, or even achieved without seeking.

Strictly speaking, transcendence cannot be forcibly sought, nor can the true be schemed for. Without the *Mysterious Registers*, one cannot hear the *Sutras of Wisdom*; without the *Jade Scriptures*, one will never see the *Divine Golden Tiger Chapters*; without ardent longing for flying transcendence, one cannot know the *Great Ultimate and Upper Clarity*.

In summary: destiny, will, essence, diligence, practicing hidden virtue, rescuing from disaster, aiding the poor and distressed, establishing benevolent deeds. Uniting these, one faces all things with a compassionate heart, never directing malice toward any living being. This is the gateway to the Dao’s essentials, the secluded chamber of attaining the Way.

chunks.original_text: 太上八术智慧灭魔神虎隐文，得者入定，生生无死，上相青童撰合成章。 若有笃志宿命应见此文，受之皆当斋戒，赍金龙玉鱼盟誓。 皆是天下万精群灵之名，千魔万妖之隐讳也。 故撰之成文，太一帝君常以鬼兵卫之，慎勿轻传。 太上大道君，爰乃自弹景龙云璈，霄音千逸，万响缠激，流徽郁勃，紫蔼回荫，玄风八发，於是玉凤延颈，金鸾整炁，龙吟碧波，虎跃神州，九啸和唱，玄钧洞无，伏兽攘袂，猛马张喉，揭岳横林，衔剑摄邪，众声纷乱，百狼玃妖。 尔乃命玉清上宫侍女安法婴、田四非、赵定珠、存云门等，合歌挥神之诗，灭精散灵之曲，其辞曰： 泛泛太霞辔，八浮造云营，神宗理灵襟，龙翰秀玉京， 金门缠蔚裕，九房朗紫琼，高驾涉北元，萧萧入无生， 朱虎导灵师，绿辕登上清，四玄明朝禁，抱华还凤城， 七难尚梵绿，拟标九元衢，宣曜宝太晖，飙眇跃景敷， 整控启素乡，河灵已前驱，阴云带夜日，烛月欻交初， 结朗未生神，携领同反无，万源泻北谷，乘空归流星， 灭景擢浮游，峨峰自霄浪，缠绵嘉乐宿，妙微挺虚向， 逸宅丹玄本，太空道赤畅，幽明秉灵符，暗推岂乖丧， 落玄表群会，生始似久梦，德隐冲内迹，至寂不觉当， 神精感太素，烟映在所之，玄响奏豪外，幽条焉能疑， 协晨鼓长扇，晖霞生在兹，绝洞溟溟流，翔翅六领台， 神王入玉虚，至无侵朱兵，九罗遘幽辽，妙会亦已平， 道藏金极章，弹调赫□荣，千龙吐渌水，九河倒竭倾， 洪蔼摄绝宅，灵浪四盖庭，齐首嶒宇，莫检形与名， 领拔纳元和，秀纵玄执理，含精灼云房，萧倅清零纪， 灵道趣兰阙，玄玄即排起，万峰但奇观，云上有琼子， 终劫协玉华，靡觉方自始，源神齐洞化，沦伏忘定征， 河侯结上观，景珠玮琳庭，理无二虚表，凝澄岂亏盈， 太阳交重阴，回拂存落冥，同任六觉外，灵唱齐一声， 运玑璇汉道，焕焕动华琼，万神腾朱马，千魔无暇生， 妖灭水火宫，真躬宝太贞。 四命北阿，理神定辔，呼召地祇，土精匿炁， 山岳藏云，九源绝灭，推校千精，执馘雷震， 北帝启道，四明奉辕，摧烂万邪，勒割酆山， 九鬼共首，千魔同身，五帝秉钺，神公吐烟， 紫明炼观，朱炁累缠，灵走夜台，精藏长绵， 毒兽万尺，所屠无亲，有何小妖，聚百累千， 交炁齐瞻，当人生门，神虎纵威，斩玃枭残， 太无奇道，至灵所甄，子今受之，永以佩身， 万试不校，千妖不干，玉华诣房，天真游旋， 讽明灵音，上朝三元。 歌毕，於是太上大道君乃命左玄玉郎郁梨玄，执紫金羽节，召太微天帝君。 太微天帝君凝化精炁，操真策虚，啸咤万神，权罗本初，手执金真，淡盻太元，忽闻命卒行，登勅驾羽灵，朱皇启道，辇甲天丁，万虎驱除，金龙御兵，玉节投景，飞华入冥，流浊焕阵，行启 日精，打碧鼓之滂浪，叩琼锺之砰砰，於是玄钧合和，广乐遏后，九凤延颈而唱啸，百龙衔津而同呴，金精踊音，八鸾翔舞，紫旗建霄，锦旄绕野，绿盖列荫，曲晨欻举，流铃交掷，月明彻响，琼玕表真，徊停五象，香华散烟，雰葩三景，轻霄纳晖，薄霞带光，鸣辔七道，八舆浮空，虚辇九千，卫以毒龙，走云赴玄，聚炁摄风，天明蓊溃，八光朦胧，真女右骑，左命灵童，倏欻千亿，已到上宫，停驾玉清，身超帝墉，徊步紫阙，稽首待通。

The *Hidden Writ of the Divine Tiger of the Eight Arts of the Most High’s Wisdom Dispelling Demons*—those who attain it enter samādhi and live without death across all lives. Compiled into a chapter by the Azure Lad of the Upper Rank.

Should one of steadfast resolve and karmic destiny encounter this text, all who receive it must first perform purification rites, present golden dragons and jade fish, and swear solemn oaths. These are the names of the ten thousand spirits and hosts of the world, the hidden taboos of a thousand demons and ten thousand specters. Thus compiled into this writ, the Lord of the Great One ever guards it with ghostly soldiers—take care not to transmit it lightly.

The Lord of the Great Dao then plucked the *Cloud Zither of the Radiant Dragon*, its celestial tones soaring in a thousand flights, myriad echoes intertwining and surging. Resplendent harmonies billowed forth, purple mists swirling in shade, while the Eight Mystic Winds arose. Thereupon the Jade Phoenix stretched its neck, the Golden Simurgh composed its qi, dragons intoned over sapphire waves, and tigers leapt upon the divine continent. Nine whistles harmonized in chorus, the Mystic Chord resonating through the void. Subdued beasts rolled up their sleeves, fierce steeds bared their throats, mountains reared across forests, and swords were clenched to seize the perverse. A tumult of voices arose, a hundred wolves and monstrous apes clamored.

Then he commanded the handmaidens of the Jade Clarity Upper Palace—An Faying, Tian Sifei, Zhao Dingzhu, and Cun Yunmen—to join in singing the *Divine Poetry of Expelling Spirits* and the *Melody of Dispersing Numinous Beings*. Its verses proclaimed:

Floating, floating, the reins of the Great Rosy Clouds,
Eightfold ascent to the Cloud Encampment.
The divine lineage orders the numinous heart,
Dragon brushes adorn the Jade Capital.
Golden gates entwine in lush abundance,
Nine chambers gleam with purple jade.
A lofty chariot crosses the Northern Origin,
Rustling into the Unborn.
The Vermilion Tiger guides the divine master,
Green shafts ascend to the Upper Clarity.
The Four Mysteries illumine the morning prohibitions,
Embracing blossoms, returning to the Phoenix City.
The Seven Perils yet bear the green of Brahman,
Aspiring to mark the Ninefold Origin’s thoroughfare.
Proclaiming the radiance of the Treasured Great Splendor,
The whirlwind dances, leaping through the unfolding light.
Ordering the reins to open the Primal Homeland,
The River Spirits have already taken the lead.
Yin clouds gird the night’s sun,
The candle-moon suddenly meets at first exchange.
Binding the luminous, the unborn spirit,
Leading together to return to the void.
Ten thousand sources pour into the Northern Valley,
Riding the void back to the streaming stars.
Extinguishing light to pluck the floating wanderer,
Peaks soar like waves in the sky.
Entwined in the abode of joyous music,
Subtle wonders emerge toward the empty.
The carefree dwelling in the cinnabar and mysterious origin,
The Great Void’s Dao flows red and unimpeded.
Dark and bright wield the numinous tally,
How could hidden reckoning stray or be lost?
The Fallen Mystery reveals the host’s assembly,
Birth’s beginning seems a long dream.
Virtue conceals its traces within the subtle,
Utter stillness unknowingly becomes.
The divine essence moves the Great Simplicity,
Mist and reflection dwell where they will.
Mystic echoes resound beyond the bold,
How could the hidden boughs give rise to doubt?
Harmonizing with the morning drum’s long fan,
Radiant rosy clouds arise here.
Cutting off the abyss’s dark and boundless flow,
Soaring wings reach the Sixfold Terrace.
The Divine King enters the Jade Void,
Utter nonbeing invades the vermilion troops.
The Nine Netherworlds meet in distant obscurity,
The wondrous assembly is already at peace.
The Dao’s treasury, the Golden Ultimate’s chapter,
Strummed and tuned to blazing glory.
A thousand dragons spew green waters,
The Nine Rivers pour out in exhaustion.
Vast mists seize the remote abode,
Numinous waves fill the Fourfold Canopy’s court.
Heads aligned, gazing toward the towering palace,
No reckoning of form or name.
Leading and drawing in the Primal Harmony,
Flourishing and freely grasping the Mystic Principle.
Containing essence, blazing in the cloud chambers,
Rustling and assisting the pure, fading records.
The numinous Dao hastens to the Orchid Gate,
The Mysterious Mysterious at once arrays itself.
Ten thousand peaks are but a marvelous sight,
Above the clouds dwell the Jade Children.
Through kalpas, harmonizing with jade splendor,
No awareness yet begins.
The source spirits equal the Cavern’s transformation,
Sinking and submitting, forgetting the signs of samādhi.
The River Lord binds the Upper Observatory,
The Radiant Pearl adorns the Jasper Court.
Principle has no duality beyond the void,
How could congealing clarity ever wane or wax?
The Great Yang exchanges with the Heavy Yin,
Turning and sweeping, abiding in the fallen dark.
Together entrusted beyond the Six Perceptions,
The numinous chant unites in a single voice.
The turning jade pivots the Han’s Dao,
Brilliant and resplendent, stirring the flowery jasper.
Ten thousand spirits mount vermilion steeds,
A thousand demons have no leisure to arise.
Specters vanish in the Palaces of Water and Fire,
The true body treasures the Great Perfection.

The Four Lifespans of the Northern Alas,
Ordering the divine, steadying the reins.
Summoning the Earth Deities,
The earth spirits conceal their qi.
Mountains and peaks hide the clouds,
The Nine Sources are cut off and extinguished.
Pushing and examining the thousand spirits,
Seizing captives with thunderous might.
The Northern Emperor opens the Dao,
The Four Illuminations attend the chariot.
Crushing and shattering the ten thousand perverse,
Carving and severing Mount Feng.
Nine ghosts share a single head,
A thousand demons share a single body.
The Five Emperors wield their axes,
The Divine Lords exhale mist.
Purple clarity refines the observance,
Vermilion qi coils in layers.
Spirits flee to the Night Terrace,
Essences hide in eternal continuity.
Poisonous beasts a thousand feet long,
Slaughtered without kinship.
What petty specters gather in hundreds or thousands,
Exchanging qi, gazing together at the Gate of Human Life?
The Divine Tiger unleashes its might,
Beheading monstrous apes and decapitating owls.
The wondrous Dao of the Great Nonbeing,
The utmost numinous selects and approves.
You who now receive this,
Forever wear it upon your person.
Ten thousand trials will not contest you,
A thousand specters will not approach.
The Jade Splendor arrives at the chamber,
Heavenly Perfected wander and circle.
Recite and illumine the numinous tones,
Ascend to pay homage to the Three Origins.

When the song concluded, the Lord of the Great Dao then commanded Yu Lixuan, the Jade Lad of the Left Mystery, to take up the Purple-Gold Feathered Staff and summon the Heavenly Emperor of the Supreme Tenuity. The Heavenly Emperor of the Supreme Tenuity condensed his refined qi, wielding the True Staff in the void. Whistling and commanding the ten thousand spirits, he marshaled the authority of the Primal Origin. Holding the Golden Truth, he gazed serenely upon the Great Origin. Suddenly hearing the command, he swiftly set forth, mounting his feathered chariot. The Vermilion Sovereign opened the Dao, and the armored Heavenly Soldiers were arrayed. Ten thousand tigers drove out the perverse, golden dragons led the troops. The Jade Staff cast its light, flying blossoms entered the dark. Turbid currents transformed the ranks, advancing to activate the Solar Essence. Striking the azure drum’s surging waves, sounding the jasper bell’s resounding peals. Thereupon the Mystic Chord harmonized, the grand music halted behind. Nine phoenixes stretched their necks and sang, a hundred dragons held the nectar in their jaws and joined in chorus. Golden essences leapt in melody, eight simurghs soared and danced. Purple banners rose into the sky, brocade pennants wound through the fields. Green canopies arrayed in shade, the winding morning suddenly arose. Flowing bells tossed and turned, their moonlit echoes penetrating. Jasper branches displayed the true, lingering amidst the Five Symbols. Fragrant blossoms scattered mist, petals of the Three Luminaries. Light rosy clouds received the radiance, thin mists girded the light. The reins rang upon the Seven Paths, the Eight Chariots floated in the void. Nine thousand empty carriages, guarded by poisonous dragons. Racing clouds hastened to the mysterious, gathering qi and seizing the wind. The heavens brightened, bursting forth, the Eight Lights hazy and indistinct. The Perfected Woman rode on the right, the Numinous Lad was commanded on the left. In an instant, a thousand myriads arrived at the Upper Palace. Halting the chariot at the Jade Clarity, transcending the Emperor’s ramparts, pacing the Purple Gates, bowing to await announcement.

chunks.original_text: 既至良久，太上大道君乃勑命侍晨四臣徐引以前，登药珠之闼，入七映内房，太微天帝君称名曰：贱臣今到，请闻大命矣。 太上大道君曰：李山渊德合七圣，为金阙之主，方当参谒十天，理命亿兆，定中元於玄机，制阴阳以齐首，拔真擢领，封河召海，断任死生，把执天威，馘灭六天，总罚三官，罗执北帝，明公侍轩，道亦高标，德弘逸远，任亦重矣，掌亦侔也，我既已说之以智慧，又复记之以消魔，智慧可以驱神，消魔可以灭邪，复授之以神虎真符，使威馘六天，咏之以挥神高章，亦助之散秽去患也。 且太微帝君所宝有金虎真符，以制天地神灵，叱之以行便得摧斩千精，佩之而往则万鬼灭形，众魔妄侵而即死，群妖窥之而目冥，乃可俱授山渊，以成其任乎。 於是太微天帝君稽首唯唯，乃解云笈，发琼函，七光映素，流日启真，九晖停曜，飞香交缠。 执符未授，顾命太微侍女纪林华、严采云、朱条烟、韩放要等，合歌金真之诗，步虚之曲，其辞曰： 太冥绝四玄，洞景寄神通。 玉台敷朱霄，绿霞有金墉。 上挹云珠岭，仰投无刃峰。 灵镜耀紫绾，蔼沬晖冲空。 冥化缠玄琅，挹节携紫童。 圆涂无凝幙，绮蔼复有重。 南排朱阜户，西踰豪缺窗。 体娇万津波，神生蹑十方。 玄归反寂辕，上响乘天龙。 冥摅飞景舆，挥铃七道游。 轻朗云尘津，欻已造玉州。 左摄玉映妻，右命金真夫。 上接飞霄贤，俯援灵妙畴。 弥缠广寒宇，披锦入神丘。 凤脑固劫龄，蕊醴反华颓。 太上宴寿稔，制命万杪阶。 三觉承玄数，纵欢焕牙回。 飙粲停琅华，紫桂何栖栖。 琳实鸣九霄，玉节征太微。 黄策遏德刃，岂罕真人晖。 弃素入无质，百象始俱遗。 豁阳丹炁颖，烂灿绛云飞。 齐契玉映静，炫悬上清畿。 神灵应冥数，顺感招兆世。 洪津浪纷蔚，并景参容裔。 峨峨金阙子，萧条入云际。 俯仰万兆变，将顺同精契。 玄栖绝寂台，清咏智与慧。 消魔灭万锋，挥诗以逐秽。 金虎承天威，摧神以匿气。 扫妖千万顷，万里无邪芥。 於焉大神割血，百精丧目，金虎奋豪，吐威放毒，收鬼无间，横截刳腹，六天共首，神灵顿局，鸟兽藏音，林草偃伏。 太元奇逸，灵文朗郁，佩之而进，得以朝玉皇，礼之於琼寝，众真诣其房。 有泄於神虎文，祸及於九宗。 有漏於金虎真符，殃逮於七祖翁。 山渊藏之，道德之英矣。 歌毕，太微帝君乃授李君金虎真符，誓陈谢而各别去。 李君既得奉受二符，及闻太上说智慧消魔之二经，并告上相青童，使与上宰四辅撰集合成为文，令常施用，以传宿命当为真人者，七百年中听三授之。 此诗希微异音，多是天地万精群灵之名，千魔毒妖之隐讳者也。 太上咏其名，以显其化，以叙其事，以盟其符矣。 神映八观，灵洞奇落，威灵之秘符，灭魔之妖，作是神虎，首其上标，金虎班其次序，智慧蔚乎文中，消魔陈其字间矣。 若夜中恐畏，但讽此二篇诗，则千精迸匿，如与万人同宿。 山川闻此诗咏，其神皆执鞭向声处而拜敬也。 况佩神金以流焕六天，何得不聚伏耶。 若有志道之士，游行五岳，欲升仙腾超，不得太微天帝及太一君讳名目金虎真符，则名不得上仙府也。 佩此符并讽诵灭魔之文，则千精进匿，如与万人同宿，山川闻此咏，其大神皆执鞭向声处拜敬也。

After a long while, the Supreme Great Dao Lord then commanded the Four Ministers of the Dawn Attendant to slowly lead forward, ascending the portal of the Elixir Pearl and entering the inner chamber of the Sevenfold Radiance. The Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity addressed him by name, saying: "Your humble servant has now arrived. I beg to hear the Great Mandate."

The Supreme Great Dao Lord replied: "Li Shanyuan’s virtue aligns with the Seven Sages, and he shall be lord of the Golden Watchtower. Soon he will pay homage to the Ten Heavens, governing the destinies of the multitudes. He shall determine the Middle Prime within the Mystery’s mechanism, regulate yin and yang to harmonize their heads, elevate the perfected and promote the worthy, seal the rivers and summon the seas, decide life and death, grasp the might of heaven, decapitate the Six Heavens, and oversee the punishments of the Three Bureaus. He shall bind the Northern Emperor, and you, Eminent Lord, shall attend his chariot. His Dao is lofty and eminent, his virtue vast and far-reaching. His charge is weighty, and his authority commensurate. I have already instructed him in wisdom, and further recorded for him the *Scripture of Vanquishing Demons*. Wisdom can drive away spirits, and vanquishing demons can extinguish evil. Moreover, I bestow upon him the True Talisman of the Divine Tiger, that he may wield its might to decapitate the Six Heavens. I chant for him the *Lofty Chapter of Commanding Spirits*, to aid him in dispersing filth and banishing calamity.

Furthermore, the Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity treasures the True Talisman of the Golden Tiger, by which the spirits of heaven and earth are controlled. With a single rebuke, he may shatter and slay a thousand essences; wearing it, he may cause ten thousand ghosts to vanish. All demons that rashly invade shall perish, and every malevolent spirit that gazes upon it shall be struck blind. Should we not together confer this upon Shanyuan, to fulfill his charge?"

Thereupon, the Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity bowed his head in assent, then untied his cloud-scribed satchel and opened the jade casket. Sevenfold radiance illuminated the plain silk, streaming sunlight revealed the truth, and ninefold brilliance paused in splendor as flying incense intertwined.

Before the talisman was bestowed, he commanded the attendants of the Grand Tenuity—Ji Linhua, Yan Caiyun, Zhu Tiaoyan, and Han Fangyao—to join in singing the *Poem of the Golden Perfected* and the *Melody of Pacing the Void*. Their verses ran:

The Supreme Darkness severs the Four Mysteries,
The cavern’s scene entrusts divine communion.
Jade terraces spread crimson auroras,
Green mists hold golden ramparts.
Above, they ladle from the Cloud-Pearl Ridge,
Gazing upward toward the Peak of No Blade.
The numinous mirror gleams with purple coils,
Misty foam radiates into the empty sky.
Mysterious transformations entwine the dark jade,
Lifting the rhythm, they lead the purple youths.
The round path has no stagnant veils,
Brocatelle mists layer upon layer.
Southward, they push open the vermilion mound’s gates,
Westward, they cross the jagged window’s gap.
Their forms dance upon ten thousand ripples,
Their spirits tread the ten directions.
The dark returns to the still axle,
The upper resonance rides the celestial dragon.
Mysteriously, they dispel the flying-scene chariot,
Brandishing bells, they roam the Seven Paths.
Light and clear, they cross the cloud-dust ford,
In an instant, they arrive at the Jade Prefecture.
On the left, they grasp the Jade Radiance’s consort,
On the right, they command the Golden Perfected’s husband.
Above, they join the soaring-aurora worthies,
Below, they aid the numinous and wondrous multitudes.
They wind through the vast Cold Palace’s halls,
Parting brocade, they enter the divine mounds.
Phoenix-brain solidifies kalpas,
Flower-nectar reverses blossoms’ decay.
The Supreme feasts in longevity’s harvest,
Decreeing destinies for the myriad branches’ steps.
The Three Awakenings uphold the dark reckoning,
Unfettered joy gleams in the ivory turn.
The whirlwind’s brilliance halts the jade’s splendor,
How the purple cassia sways!
The forest’s fruit rings through the nine auroras,
Jade staves march toward the Grand Tenuity.
The yellow writ restrains the blade of virtue—
How rare the radiance of the perfected!
Discarding the plain, they enter the formless,
A hundred images begin to vanish together.
The yang’s cinnabar qi’s tip bursts forth,
Resplendent, the crimson clouds take flight.
In accord with the Jade Radiance’s stillness,
Dazzling, they hang in the Upper Clarity’s precincts.
Spirits and numina respond to the dark reckoning,
Following resonance, they summon the world’s omens.
Vast ford’s waves surge in profusion,
Joining scenes, they mingle with the countenance’s descendants.
Majestic, the Golden Watchtower’s scion,
Desolate, he enters the cloud’s verge.
Looking up and down, the myriad changes shift—
He will comply, in harmony with the essence’s pact.
The dark perches on the Stillness Terrace,
Clearly chanting wisdom and intelligence.
Vanquishing demons extinguishes ten thousand blades,
Brandishing verse to expel filth.
The Golden Tiger bears heaven’s might,
Subduing spirits to conceal their qi.
Sweeping away a thousand myriad acres of demons,
For ten thousand leagues, no evil speck remains.

Thereupon, the great spirits severed blood, the hundred essences lost their sight. The Golden Tiger bared its fangs, spitting might and releasing poison. It seized ghosts without pause, slicing open bellies and severing heads. The Six Heavens bowed together, spirits and numina instantly cowered. Birds and beasts hid their cries, forests and grasses prostrated themselves.

The Supreme Prime’s marvels were extraordinary, the numinous script luminous and lush. Wearing it and advancing, one may pay court to the Jade Emperor, offering rites in the jeweled chamber where the host of perfected gather.

Should the Divine Tiger’s script be leaked, calamity shall reach the nine clans. Should the True Talisman of the Golden Tiger be divulged, misfortune shall extend to the seven ancestral forebears. Shanyuan, guard it well—you are the flower of the Dao and virtue.

When the song concluded, the Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity bestowed upon Lord Li the True Talisman of the Golden Tiger. They swore oaths, expressed gratitude, and each departed.

Lord Li, having received the two talismans and heard the Supreme’s discourses on the *Scripture of Wisdom* and the *Scripture of Vanquishing Demons*, then instructed the Azure Lad of the Upper Prime to compile them with the Four Assistants of the Upper Minister into a single text, to be employed regularly and transmitted to those destined to become perfected in the next seven hundred years, permitting three transmissions.

These verses’ subtle and wondrous sounds mostly comprise the hidden names of heaven, earth, the myriad essences, and the host of spirits, as well as the secret appellations of a thousand demons, poisonous beings, and malevolent spirits. The Supreme chants their names to manifest their transformations, to narrate their affairs, and to seal their talismans.

The divine radiance surveys the eight vistas, the numinous cavern’s marvels are wondrously arrayed. The secret talismans of might and the demon-vanquishing charms—this Divine Tiger leads their ranks, the Golden Tiger follows in order. Wisdom flourishes within the text, and vanquishing demons is set forth between its lines.

Should one feel fear or dread in the night, merely reciting these two poems will cause a thousand essences to scatter and hide, as if lodging with ten thousand people. When mountains and rivers hear this chant, their spirits shall all wield whips, turning toward the sound to bow in reverence.

How much more so when wearing the divine gold to illumine the Six Heavens—how could they not gather and submit? If a scholar of the Dao’s resolve travels the Five Peaks, desiring to ascend as an immortal and soar beyond, without the True Talisman of the Golden Tiger bearing the taboo names of the Celestial Emperor of the Grand Tenuity and the Lord of the Great Unity, his name shall not be recorded in the immortal’s register.

Wearing this talisman and reciting the demon-vanquishing scripture, a thousand essences shall scatter and hide, as if lodging with ten thousand people. When mountains and rivers hear this chant, their great spirits shall all wield whips, turning toward the sound to bow in reverence.

*The Wondrous True Scripture of the Supreme Dao on Wisdom and the Dispelling of Demons, Scroll Three*

**Chapter on Guarding the One**

The Supreme Dao addressed the Lord Emperor of the Golden Portal, saying: All mortals of courage and might who follow the precepts and regulations, restrain their minds and bodies, accumulate merit and virtue, and eternally become great sages must do so by guarding the One.

The One is formless yet capable of response; when response reaches its limit, form arises. Effects follow causes, and the One alternates between existence and non-existence. It is boundless and infinite, without labor or loss, without decrease or increase, without fault or burden, without death or birth. The birthless is eternally born, and the eternally born is deathless. The birth of the deathless gives rise to all things, and all things receive life from this deathless source. The deathless can generate life, creating countless beings. Those who guard it attain wisdom; those who abandon it fall into folly. Folly leads to death, while wisdom preserves life.

Life is precious and desired by all, for all delight in life and detest death. Yet those who seek life fail to live, and those who fear death hasten their demise. Failing to grasp the Dao of life and death, they stray from their aspirations. To not stray from one’s aspirations depends entirely on wisdom. Wisdom first arises from knowing the One. The One generates qi, and qi begets mutual generation. One must neither forget nor neglect it, nor obstruct or suppress it. To suppress qi in pursuit of life severs the generative qi, and severance leads to death, from which there is no return to life. Enduring eternal suffering, the wise awaken to this truth. To awaken late is to be without knowledge. Lack of knowledge plunges one into ignorance, and the ignorant are difficult to transform. Though transformed, they remain unaware; though aware, they do not diligently practice; though diligent, they cannot persist; though persistent, they cannot refine their practice; though refined, they leak and dissipate—this is called lack of resolve. Lack of resolve leads to delusion, and delusion, if uncorrected, is not wisdom. Wisdom is to turn from delusion and enter the Dao, to abandon the perverse and return to the upright.

Guard the generative qi, for qi begets mutual generation. The generative qi transforms and unites, dividing into three: the first is the Primordial Origin, the second is the Originating Cavern, and the third is the Mysterious Void. The lower is the Mysterious Qi, which governs the Void, curing illness and dispelling calamities—one may ride the Void. Afterward, inscribe upon gold plates nine inches in length, four inches in breadth, and three *fen* in thickness, and use them to seal the malevolent spirits of mountains and rivers, thereby commanding the true essences of the Five Peaks.

Following the ingestion and wearing of the talismans, meditate earnestly upon the Three Ones. Between the eyebrows, one *cun* inward lies the Hall of Light; two *cun* inward, the Cavern Chamber; three *cun* inward, the Upper Cinnabar Field, also called the Mud-Pill Palace, one *cun* square, where purple *qi* surges to the heavens. Within it is a solar image, nine *cun* in circumference, illuminating ninety thousand *li* beyond. My form transforms—now vast, now minute—swift as a flash, the body forgotten, all held in the mind’s intent.

The Upper Prime Child resides beneath the canopy of the Mud-Pill Palace, named *Xuan Ning Tian*, styled *San Yuan Xian*, also called *Bo Wu Shang* and *Bo Shi Hua*, and holds the title Lord Emperor of the Mud-Pill Heaven. To his right is the Imperial Minister, named *Zhao Le Jing*, styled *Zhong Xuan*, also called *Qi Fei* and *Chang Fu*. Both appear naked, their forms like infants.

The heart is the Middle Cinnabar Field, called the Crimson Palace, one *cun* square, where vermilion mist ascends to the heavens. Within it is a solar image, seven *cun* in diameter, illuminating seventy thousand *li* beyond. My form transforms into the Middle Prime Perfected, named *Shen Yun Zhu*, styled *Zi Nan Dan*, also called *Sheng Bo* and *Shi Yun Ju*, and holds the title Cinnabar Sovereign of the Crimson Palace. To his right is the Assisting Sovereign Minister, named *Zhong Guang Jian*, styled *Si Hua Ling*, also called *You Che Bo* and *Chong Shi Hua*. Both appear naked, their forms like infants, seated facing each other.

Three *cun* below the navel lies the Gate of Destiny, the Cinnabar Field Palace, one *cun* square, where white *qi* surges to the heavens. Within it is a solar image, five *cun* in circumference, illuminating fifty thousand *li* beyond. My form transforms into the Lower Prime Infant, named *Shi Ming Jing*, styled *Yuan Yang Chang*, also called *Ying’er Tai* and *Bo Shi Yuan*, and holds the title Primordial King of the Yellow Court. To his right is the Guardian Stabilizing Minister, named *Gui Shang Ming*, styled *Gu Xia Xuan*, also called *Feng Shen Bo* and *Cheng Guang Sheng*. Both appear naked, their forms like infants, seated facing each other.

By meditating upon the Three Ones over time, they will manifest. Their manifestation brings divine penetration and the attainment of wisdom. Those who cultivate wisdom yet fail to refine their focus, or whose unity remains unperfected and unmanifest, whose spirits remain unintegrated, will still encounter misfortune. Though matters may be unclear, even if one has grasped the method, life is not yet secure. Those who, knowing themselves, scorn others—what others can achieve, fools dismiss as trivial, paying no heed. With intent unheld, understanding eludes them. Though comprehension may not be essential, it is still employed. Employing it with harmonious light, the foolish find it difficult, the wise find it easy. To abandon it entirely is not the Way, nor is clinging to it. Failing to align with the world, one cannot bring aid—this is not wisdom.

All arts and skills, games and entertainments, male and female spirits, beauty and ugliness, diverse methods, deeds of body, speech, and mind, sounds and sights, touch and obstruction, movement and stillness, concealment and revelation, transformation and illusion, floating and sinking, existence and nonexistence, authority and substance, orthodoxy and heterodoxy, strength and weakness, ominous words—all actions under heaven—if even one remains unmastered, this is not wisdom.

Those who cultivate wisdom must embrace the One and never depart from it. To depart from the One is to lose wisdom, for all is the work of the Three Pengs. The Upper Peng enslaves the hun and po, and greed and lust bring aging. The Middle Peng enslaves the spirit of consciousness, and anger and resentment bring illness. The Lower Peng enslaves essence and will, and ignorance brings death. Death returns one to the ranks of ghosts, called corpses. The suffering of corpse-ghosts is the work of the Three Pengs, hence their name. Fierce and unruly, they are difficult to subdue. Failing to subdue them, the body’s spirits grow vexed, harmed and broken, sinking into the wind-blades of darkness, enduring torment and agony, a sorrowful eternal night, endless as the kalpas of dust—how can one not fear this?

The wise first govern the Three Ghosts: restrain greed and lust, avoid entanglement in disputes, suppress anger and resentment, and prevent lawsuits and strife. When strife ceases, disputes end, and punishment does not reach death. Death arises from stagnation, and stagnation from ignorance. Disputes and strife provoke extreme exertion, heedless of retreat, leading to death and calamity. The suffering of calamity is cruel and bitter—regret comes too late.

Thus, in cultivation, one must first embrace the One. Embracing the One and preserving the spirit, all affairs flow without stagnation. Acting without acting, daily diminishing to perfect virtue—though greed and lust may briefly arise, one can repent and change. Though anger and resentment may occasionally flare, one can suppress and transform them, ultimately avoiding stagnation. To avoid stagnation is to escape death and attain longevity.

Yet fleeting greed and lust are easy to cling to but hard to dispel. Greed for pines may be easy, but lust and anger are far more difficult. All sentient beings wish to prevail. When others impose upon me, the mind cannot bear it. Unable to bear it, one retaliates, and disputes arise. Once arisen, they are hard to halt, leading to death and ruin.

Swear devotion to the Dao, guard the One and never depart. It is easier to refrain from offending others than to prevent others from offending oneself. If offended, do not retaliate; let go of vengeance. If vengeance must be taken, do so with the Dao, offering further enlightenment, dissolving enmity, and entering together into truth. Without harboring resentment, forever united in the source—those who deviate from this path are not wise.

The wise lead by example, as the Most High knows all below. The refined words form teachings, and the teachings are chanted in seven stanzas, as follows:

1. To know the One yet not guard it, or guard it without firmness, or hold it without constancy—this is not wisdom.
2. To know the Three yet not govern them, or govern them without strictness, or maintain strictness without permanence—this is not wisdom.
3. To know peril yet not avoid it, or avoid it without secrecy, or maintain secrecy without constancy—this is not wisdom.
4. To know words yet not cherish them, or cherish them without encouragement, or encourage without fruition—this is not wisdom.
5. To know the world can be governed yet not stabilize it, or stabilize it without flourishing—this is not wisdom.
6. To know the Dao can be practiced yet not clarify it, or clarify it without grandeur—this is not wisdom.

chunks.original_text: 七知无知有，有不能精，精不能审，非智慧也。 右七觉七吟，自然文字。 昔者太上，及今吾身，将来登极，皆吟此文，消诸魔试，灭众邪疑，疑去迷除，回末归本，本难即至，末者共营，一懃一息，功过推移，往返之间，逢随即至，须应须感，感以动之，开悟愚暗，暗者得明，明还正觉，觉一切无，无中有妙，妙炁变化，练伪成真，真由五德，德会六通，通资七觉，觉缘此吟，吟应彼感，感显生名，名之为应，承因入果，有证有征，无差无忒，七五中六，六变相成，彼感尚征，动之令着，迹由我感，我有感名，名异实同，征着为异，异乎 寂动，对岸初分，分一为二，三生六成，成六六迹，六迹一心，心源本一，流派无穷，大分有六，出没所关，行之出三界之上，废之入九幽之下，智惠行六，能超三界，度九幽苦，故名六度，六六三十六天，咸共修行六度。 一曰能懃，行善不懈也，二曰能信，笃道无忘也，三曰能雌，守一用柔也，四曰能终，如始无败也，五曰能谏诤，止恶不忤，物我俱全也，六曰能弃酒色，和光通神，同尘种道，无昏无滞，是智慧也。 是智慧也者，清明为常，祭酒不昏，不冥不滞，通神济众，系道种人，有而不乱，故名为弃，弃在无滞，滞在违科，违科则昏迷，非智慧也。 习学之俦，存神慕德，未能无待，省约示廉，遵崇日损，表廉神明，供养贤德，申己至诚，依按法制，不得滂沲。 酒为水谷之精，善能宣通气液，节之者接灵益性，纵之者乖神损生，耽湎致无，非智惠也。 源一自然，玄二成象，两炁流润，和合三三，三一周布，圣普同年，盛德充盈，两半生生，两半成一，一一无穷，弃德好色，不顾种人，恣欲逞情，非智慧也。 智慧之流，知日偃月，皇灵所崇，生生为急，自弘及物，传化不休，慎勿乖此。 二炁失和，或阴阴相结，或阳阳相缠，或男多聚女，或女饶集男，贵贱混杂，道俗纷纭，妬忌忿怼，隔绝为高，致断种灭胤，堕落不毛，求还未期，悔所无及。 或男耽美女，女恋华男，交非妻妾，合非婿夫，奸邪乱正，生杀乖真，不能改悟，非智慧也。 智慧清明，不邪不乱，故登三清，玉京紫极，极道之源，由清所诣也。 一切含炁，无能无欲，欲有深浅，事有重轻，轻者相触，不止则重。 己无犯人，人犯必受，受有怨言，言不能释，非智慧也。 若尊卑内外，有相犯触，和颜悦色，譬喻解说，流泣悲酸，呵骂胁吓，种种方便，趣令得止。 思惟权实，一引一抑，勿致愤激，小更成大，遂不止者，宿命恶深，圣所未知，慈念勿责，密愧不能止之。 慎莫出口敞灵，智惠有所无奈何，正是此等，又不得过自耻恨，弃彼不复存之，或不戒视败，任人纵横，无慈救功，非智慧也。 智惠者守静存神，忘形定炁，炁通无诤，诤可止也。 忘形神存，谏多从也，若忘神存形，利我割彼，彼不信从，反加憾恨，久后成殃，非智慧也。 凡有所为，为道是始，众事云云，皆为粗末，粗末可舍，妙始叵乖，乖妙逐粗，非智慧也。 智慧者发心动口，动静其身，行道为始，始善善终，终不违始，练心日精，善行精进，功德惟新，不能尔者，非智慧也。 凡立身心，同口思道，抱一统万，习弱尊柔，江海多容，故为川王，能忍辱者，受垢成主，不堪困苦，不辨臧非，不任烦恼，非智慧也。

7. To know the absence of knowing yet not refine it, or refine it without precision, or maintain precision without scrutiny—this is not wisdom.

These seven awakenings are chanted in seven stanzas, forming natural scripture. From the Most High of old to my own self today, and for those who will ascend in the future, all recite this text to dispel demonic trials, extinguish all heretical doubts, remove confusion and banish delusion, return from the peripheral to the fundamental. When the fundamental is firmly established, the peripheral is jointly cultivated. With each diligent effort and each breath, merit and transgression shift. In the cycle of going and returning, encounter and response arise instantly. As soon as there is resonance, there is movement; through movement, the dull and benighted are enlightened. The benighted attain clarity, and clarity returns to true awakening. Awakening perceives all as nothingness, and within nothingness lies the wondrous. The wondrous qi transforms and refines the false into the real. The real arises from the five virtues, and the virtues converge in the six penetrations. The penetrations are sustained by the seven awakenings, and the awakenings are chanted in response to resonance. The resonance manifests as a name, and the name is called "response." Following causes, one enters effects, with verification and evidence, without deviation or error.

Within the seven and five lies the six, and the six undergo transformations to achieve completion. Even resonance awaits verification; movement is made manifest. Traces arise from my resonance, and I possess the name of resonance. Though names differ, their essence is the same. Verification and manifestation create distinction, distinguishing stillness from movement. The far shore is initially divided: one divides into two, two generates three, and three completes the six. The six forms thirty-six traces, and the thirty-six traces converge in one mind. The source of the mind is fundamentally one, yet its streams are boundless. The great divisions number six, governing emergence and submergence. Practicing this ascends beyond the Three Realms; neglecting it descends into the Nine Dark Abysses. Wisdom and practice of the six enable transcendence beyond the Three Realms and deliverance from the suffering of the Nine Abysses—hence the name "Six Perfections." The thirty-six heavens of the six sixes all cultivate the Six Perfections:

1. **Diligence**: Practicing goodness without slackening.
2. **Faith**: Devoted to the Dao without forgetfulness.
3. **Yielding**: Guarding the One with softness.
4. **Perseverance**: Maintaining the beginning without failure.
5. **Admonition**: Halting evil without resistance, preserving both self and others.
6. **Renunciation**: Abandoning wine and lust, harmonizing light to commune with spirits, blending with the world to plant the Dao, free from confusion and stagnation—this is wisdom.

This wisdom is ever clear and luminous. Even when offering libations, one remains undimmed, neither benighted nor stagnant, communing with spirits and aiding the multitude. It binds to the Dao and cultivates humanity, present yet not disordered—hence the name "renunciation." Renunciation lies in non-stagnation; stagnation lies in violating precepts. Violating precepts leads to confusion—this is not wisdom.

For those who study and practice, preserving the spirit and revering virtue, though not yet free from dependence, they cultivate frugality to demonstrate integrity. They honor daily diminution, manifest integrity to the spirit, offer sustenance to the worthy and virtuous, express utmost sincerity, and adhere to the laws and regulations—without excess.

Wine is the essence of grains and water, capable of circulating qi and fluids. Moderation in it connects with the numinous and benefits nature; indulgence in it disrupts the spirit and harms life. Surrendering to intoxication leads to oblivion—this is not wisdom.

The source is naturally one; the mysterious two forms images. The two qi flow and moisten, harmonizing into three threes. The three ones circulate universally, and the sages share the same year. Overflowing virtue fills all, and the two halves generate life. The two halves become one, and each one is boundless. Abandoning virtue for lust, neglecting the cultivation of humanity, indulging desires and following passions—this is not wisdom.

The flow of wisdom knows the sun’s decline and the moon’s waning. The august spirits revere it, prioritizing the generation of life. From self-cultivation to benefiting others, transmission and transformation never cease. Take care not to deviate from this.

When the two qi lose harmony, either yin congeals with yin or yang entangles with yang. Men may gather excessively with women, or women may cluster around men. Noble and base intermingle, Daoists and laypeople jostle in confusion. Jealousy, resentment, and anger arise, leading to isolation and exaltation. This severs lineage and extinguishes descendants, causing downfall into barrenness. The hope of return remains distant, and regret comes too late.

Some men indulge in beautiful women, and women cling to handsome men. Their unions are not with wives or concubines, nor with husbands or betrothed. Licentiousness disrupts propriety, and life and death deviate from the real. Failing to awaken and reform—this is not wisdom.

Wisdom is clear and luminous, neither deviant nor disordered. Thus, one ascends to the Three Clarities, the Purple Pole of the Jade Capital. The source of the ultimate Dao is reached through purity.

All beings containing qi are without ability or desire. Desires vary in depth, and matters differ in weight. Light transgressions involve contact; if unchecked, they become grave.

If one does not offend others, yet others offend, one must endure. Enduring with resentment and words unrelieved—this is not wisdom.

When superiors and inferiors, inner and outer circles, transgress against one another, respond with a kind countenance and joyful demeanor. Use analogies and explanations, weeping and sorrow, scolding and threats—employ every expedient to halt the offense. Consider the provisional and the real, now guiding, now restraining. Avoid provoking anger, lest minor matters escalate. If the offense persists, it is due to deep karmic evil, unknown even to the sages. Compassionately refrain from blame, silently ashamed of being unable to stop it.

Take care not to speak recklessly and expose the spirit. Wisdom may find itself powerless—this is such a case. Yet do not excessively shame or resent, abandoning the other without further regard. Nor should one fail to guard against failure, allowing others to act unchecked without compassionate aid—this is not wisdom.

Wisdom guards stillness and preserves the spirit, forgetting form and stabilizing qi. Qi flows without contention, and contention can be halted. Forgetting form while preserving the spirit allows admonitions to be heeded. But if one forgets the spirit while preserving form, seeking personal gain at others’ expense, others will not trust or follow. Instead, resentment grows, and calamity arises later—this is not wisdom.

For all undertakings, the beginning lies in the Dao. All other matters are coarse and peripheral. The peripheral may be abandoned, but the wondrous beginning must not be forsaken. Forsaking the wondrous to pursue the coarse—this is not wisdom.

Wisdom arises in the mind, moves the mouth, and stirs the body. Practicing the Dao is the beginning; a good beginning ensures a good end. The end does not deviate from the beginning. Refining the mind daily, good conduct advances, and merit and virtue are ever renewed. Those unable to do so—this is not wisdom.

In establishing body and mind, align the mouth with thoughts of the Dao. Embrace the One to unify the myriad, practice weakness and honor softness. The rivers and seas contain much, thus they are lords of streams. Those who endure humiliation receive filth and become masters. Unable to bear hardship, discern right from wrong, or endure affliction—this is not wisdom.

chunks.original_text: 智慧者无坏二相，物我同一，是非不足论，论之不苟执，苦乐不须辩，辩之不用申，行善不自伐，受谤不自陈，心殊此者，非智慧也。 凡生受生，生生最贵，贵道重经，崇师相系，此为三宝，宝真无价，三不可偏，偏则泥滞，周则圆通，通则济众，众济由乎三尊，尊体成一，一三应感，有隐有显，有嘿有语，有交有言。 道宝无形，隐为化本，经有文字，显为教端，师有形言，出处为法，语嘿随时，长存为最。 最要之训，度无量人，敬信三宝，存笃无忘，斋醮招神，持戒行道，谨慎不亏，全而无破。 破亏即首，改往修来，不重犯者，必得度世，不信不持，不改不悔，不能度世，非智慧也。 凡闻大道，誓能懃行，行善不休，损己济物。 有文武才者，以识解施人； 有勇炁力者，以执劳施人； 有势位财者，以荣禄施人。 无此三者，以善心施人，见他佳事，助之欢憘，见他避事，助之愁忧，於彼虽无即益，缘感久久相关，彼有善人赞佑之福，己受善心随憘之报，报同布施，增长不休，积积无亏。 自然有才力势位也。 无此四施，非智慧也。 智慧者行此四事，为六度之先，学空不空，为圣证之极，极不空空，不空不空，空洞无矣。 无有有焉，有有不有，无无不无，无无精粗，有有善恶，有无善恶，无有精粗，有无相生，精粗相形，不能究竟，非智慧者。 了然净明，明而不耀，用行舍藏，凡不能测，正心治身，检口守寂，三业无违，道足神具，沈浮自在，高举六通，号为梵行，行高於俗，去地升乎天。 六度冠梵行，七觉登大罗，非下圣中真所可跋及，次仙贤者，岂能逮哉？ 至於小智大迷，小惠大惑，执无着有，彼此相伤，邪来干试，不度不知，遂陷退方，非智慧也。 智慧贤者，精进进功，功德超殊，亦得上合，合则魔消，宜须勇猛，后身先达，子谛宣之。 金阙帝君稽首奉行。 洞真太上说智慧消魔真经卷之三竟 #1『无极』原作『死极』，据文义改。 洞真太上说智慧消魔真经卷之四 证圣品

The wise discern no duality of destruction; self and other are one, right and wrong need not be debated, and if debated, one does not cling obstinately. Suffering and joy require no distinction, and if distinguished, no need to expound. In doing good, one does not boast; when slandered, one does not defend. Those whose minds differ from this are not wise.

All life receives life, and the living are most precious. To honor the Dao and revere the scriptures, to esteem the master—these form the Three Treasures, treasures of true and priceless worth. The Three must not be partial; partiality leads to stagnation, while completeness brings perfect harmony. Harmony enables salvation of the many, and the salvation of the many arises from the Three Honored Ones. The honored body becomes one, and the one responds to the three with resonance—now hidden, now manifest, now silent, now speaking, now interacting, now discoursing.

The Dao-Treasure is formless, hidden as the root of transformation. The scriptures bear written words, manifest as the beginning of teaching. The master has form and speech, whose comings and goings constitute the Dharma. Speech and silence follow the moment, but enduring presence is supreme.

The most essential teaching delivers countless beings. Reverently believe in the Three Treasures, cherish them steadfastly without forgetfulness. Through fasting and ritual, summon the spirits; uphold precepts and practice the Dao. Be cautious and unblemished, whole and unbroken. If broken or blemished, repent past transgressions and cultivate the future. Those who do not repeat their faults will surely attain deliverance. Those who do not believe, do not uphold, do not reform, do not repent—cannot attain deliverance and are not wise.

Upon hearing the Great Dao, vow to practice diligently without cease, doing good without rest, diminishing the self to aid others. Those with literary or martial talent share their understanding with others. Those with courage and strength offer their labor to others. Those with power, rank, or wealth bestow honor and bounty upon others. Those lacking these three offer the goodness of their hearts to others—rejoicing when they see others’ good deeds and assisting them, grieving when they see others shun their duties and aiding them in sorrow. Though no immediate benefit may come to them, over time, resonance will arise. When others receive the blessings of praise and support, they themselves gain the reward of a joyful heart. This reward is like almsgiving, ever increasing without depletion. Thus, naturally, one acquires talent, strength, power, and rank.

Those who lack these four offerings are not wise. The wise practice these four as the foundation of the Six Perfections. To study emptiness yet not be empty is the ultimate attainment of the sage. The ultimate is not empty emptiness; not empty, not empty—emptiness is utterly void. There is no "having," yet "having" does not persist. There is no "non-having," yet "non-having" is not absolute. "Non-having" transcends refinement and coarseness; "having" entails good and evil. Good and evil arise from "having" and "non-having," which in turn give rise to one another. Refinement and coarseness take shape in contrast, yet one cannot fathom their ultimate nature—this is not wisdom.

Lucid and pure, radiant yet not dazzling, active when needed, withdrawn when appropriate—ordinary minds cannot fathom this. Rectify the mind and govern the body, restrain the mouth and guard stillness. The three karmas do not transgress; the Dao is fulfilled and the spirit complete. Floating and sinking at will, soaring with the six penetrations—this is called the Brahmanic practice, loftier than the mundane, ascending from earth to heaven. The Six Perfections crown the Brahmanic practice; the Seven Awakenings ascend to the Great Web. Neither lesser sages nor middling perfected ones can approach this, nor can the next rank of immortals and worthies attain it.

As for those of petty wisdom and great delusion, petty kindness and great confusion—clinging to non-being while grasping at being, harming one another—when the demonic comes to test them, they neither cross over nor awaken, thus falling into retrogression. This is not wisdom.

The wise and worthy advance with diligence, their merit and virtue surpassing all. They too may ascend to union, and in union, demons vanish. One must be resolute and courageous, attaining realization in a future life before the present one. O disciples, heed this!

The Golden Portal Emperor bows his head and reverently practices.

*Thus concludes the third scroll of* The Supreme Cavern-Real One’s Scripture on Wisdom Dispelling Demons.

chunks.original_text: 太上告青童君曰：众圣积功，因缘致果，果极证备，妙姿绝伦，救度三十六天，故得三十六相，生成八十一品，故得八十一好，一切大感，共睹具形，小感篇应，各现多少，少现多藏，凡不能觉。 是以众圣真体无定，质定有常，无增无减，知之者希，故为独贵。 然志学之士，通照虽未圆周，至於所见，随识觌奇。 识眉眼者，瞩眉眼特异； 识鼻口者，觉鼻口超殊，如是三十有六，各随识明，明极识遍，乃具朗焉。 一切含炁，同少异多，多无鞅数，少极乎一，一未可至，此同路遐，方须治练，练多还少，少未至一，尚有三十六阶，阶为一天，有一巨异，巨异为一，天之极，极三十六者，乃会一源。 是以会之之方，各立科术，法迹参差，或同或异，异同之根，以善为本，本一分应，成三十六，三炁三界，备在其中，色通其外，外得忘言，得之三十有六，三十六天，各有其一，绝胜之相，太上备有。 诸天天人，真人仙人，圣人神人，各有多少。 诸世间人，帝王公侯，至于凡庶，又各有多少。 富贵而夭，贫贱而寿，无家宅宇，而有师君，有宫第舍，而无资待，或多财宝不事衣冠，或丰饰味不营屋室，乃至树下草庵，名闻高显，或华堂丽苑，以振芳风。 又有琼台无道，石户有德，参差亿绪，胜负万端。 上有下事，下有上业，因缘不同，修行各异，不得相非，非则伤识，识神全通，通在五德，德五能备，诸迹可忘，忘迹而迹存，自然相好，具足三十六，则贵富才明，威严光彩，超众绝伦，宫宇城邑，宝盖床帷，香花伎乐，侍卫参罗，文武羽翼，幢鼓高宏，风云清和，动静相附，日月炎光，万色衣冕，百和滋味，身口丰盈。 须与不须，适意自在，无上真人，太一元君，积学习善，究竟得斯，斯未得者，转轮生死，死生苦乐，一有一无，识不能通，滞则失伦，伦失堕恶，未有还期，期还向善。 是今学人，各精自揆，何有何无，求其所无，不滞所有，有能赡物，无则自臻。 凡有钱财，而无才解，宜行布施，不生吝心，轻财贵道，才解日新。 若有宅宇，而无康宁，宜纳贤圣，舍住真仙，心无悔惜，忧患自消。 若有衣食，而无长年，宜减身割口，供养明师，寻求奇方，修习妙术，心不懈怠，必保延生。 若有才智，而无居粮，宜藏明内观，密化后生，开导一切，不名其功，谦退晦迹，心不怀疑，神明所护，人鬼所崇，自得广宇，天宫福堂，衣食灵异，侍卫鲜华。 凡如此类，以推众事，事自现彰，不复具记。 明者得之，舍有而求无，无不必得，得无在无滞，无滞在不拘。 彼求则与，无固执焉，此为无滞，非为舍也； 彼虽不求，有之劳虑，弃避与他，是名为舍，非无滞也，舍此与彼，滞此之无，尚非道也。 又求而与之，我虽不执，彼得成灾，此粗不滞，亦非道也。 道不滞妙，妙者照明，我舍无损，彼得有益，是名为道，智慧人也。 施与多方，宜与不宜，得宜者是智慧，失宜者是愚痴，痴在虽施，乖智慧也。 又物来求我，详量实虚，虚者试我也，实者凭我也，凭者有善恶，试者有精粗，粗试者破而摧之，精试者辞而谢之，谢之者圣师。 善神以事试我，我无妙德，德未备充，致试今来，精识意趣，已知已了，无复惑心，以此辞之，是为智慧。

The Most High addressed the Azure Lad:

"The host of sages accumulate merit, and through karmic conditions attain fruition. When fruition reaches its apex and realization is complete, their wondrous forms transcend all comparison. Having delivered the thirty-six heavens, they thus possess the thirty-six marks. Having perfected the eighty-one grades, they thus possess the eighty-one excellences. Great perceptions all behold their full manifestation, while lesser perceptions receive partial responses—each appearing in greater or lesser measure, with the lesser concealing the greater. The common folk cannot perceive this.

Thus, the true bodies of the host of sages are without fixed form, yet their essential nature is constant, neither increasing nor diminishing. Few know this, and so it is uniquely prized. Yet for those who set their minds on learning, though their penetrating insight may not yet be complete, what they do perceive reveals wonders according to their understanding. Those who recognize the eyes and brows behold their eyes and brows as extraordinary; those who discern the nose and mouth perceive their nose and mouth as surpassing all. Thus, for each of the thirty-six marks, perception follows the clarity of one’s knowledge. When clarity reaches its apex and knowledge becomes all-encompassing, full illumination is attained.

All beings that contain qi share this principle, differing only in degree—some in abundance beyond measure, others in the barest minimum, even to the point of one. Yet even one remains unattainable, for this shared path is distant. Only through cultivation and refinement can one proceed. Refining the many returns them to the few; yet before the few are reduced to one, there remain thirty-six stages, each corresponding to a heaven. Each stage possesses a great distinction, and when these distinctions are unified, they reach the apex of the heavens. The apex of the thirty-six heavens converges in a single source.

Thus, the methods of convergence vary, each establishing its own teachings and techniques. The paths of the Dharma diverge, sometimes aligning, sometimes differing. The root of these differences lies in goodness. From one root, a single branch responds, forming the thirty-six. The three qi and three realms are all contained within. Form extends beyond, and beyond form, words are forgotten. Those who attain this in the thirty-six heavens—each of the thirty-six heavens possesses one—gain the most surpassing marks, which the Most High fully embodies.

The celestial beings of the heavens, the perfected, the immortals, the sages, and the divine—each possesses these marks in greater or lesser measure. Among worldly people, from emperors and kings to dukes and nobles, down to the common folk, each also possesses them in varying degrees. Some enjoy wealth and nobility yet die young; others live in poverty and lowliness yet attain long life. Some lack homes and dwellings yet have masters and lords; others possess palaces and mansions yet lack resources. Some amass treasures yet do not adorn themselves with robes and crowns; others indulge in fine food and adornment yet do not build houses. Some dwell beneath trees or in thatched huts yet gain fame and renown; others reside in splendid halls and fragrant gardens yet spread their fragrance far and wide. Some live in jade towers yet lack the Dao; others dwell in stone huts yet possess virtue. The threads of these variations are countless, their outcomes manifold.

The superior may engage in inferior affairs, while the inferior may pursue superior endeavors. Karmic conditions differ, and cultivation takes many forms. One must not disparage others, for disparagement harms perception. When the spirit of perception is fully awakened, it resides in the five virtues. When the five virtues are complete, all traces may be forgotten. Forgetting the traces, the traces remain—naturally manifesting the marks of excellence. When the thirty-six are fully possessed, one gains nobility, wealth, talent, and wisdom, along with majesty, radiance, and brilliance that surpass all others. Palaces and cities, jeweled canopies and bed curtains, fragrant flowers and music, attendants and guards, civil and martial aides, banners and drums—all resound in grandeur. Wind and clouds harmonize, movement and stillness align. The blazing light of the sun and moon, robes and crowns of myriad hues, a hundred harmonious flavors—body and speech abound in abundance. Whether needed or not, all is at ease and free. The supreme perfected and the Primordial Sovereign of the Great One, through accumulating learning and practicing goodness, ultimately attain this. Those who have not yet attained this remain bound to the turning wheel of birth and death, where suffering and joy, existence and non-existence alternate. If perception cannot penetrate this, stagnation leads to disorder, and disorder leads to falling into evil, with no return in sight. Only by turning toward goodness can one find the way back.

Now, let those who study examine themselves closely: what do they possess, and what do they lack? Seek what is lacking, and do not cling to what is already possessed. Those who can provide for others will naturally attain what they lack. For those who have wealth but lack talent and understanding, it is fitting to practice generosity without stinginess, valuing the Dao over material goods. Their talent and understanding will then renew daily. For those who have dwellings but lack peace and well-being, it is fitting to welcome the worthy and the sagely, offering their homes to true immortals, without regret or attachment. Sorrows and troubles will then naturally dissolve. For those who have clothing and food but lack long life, it is fitting to reduce bodily comforts and share with enlightened teachers, seeking rare methods and practicing wondrous arts without slackening. They will surely secure extended life. For those who possess talent and wisdom but lack shelter and provisions, it is fitting to cultivate inner vision and secretly transform future lives, guiding all beings without claiming merit. Humility and concealment, without doubt in the heart, will draw the protection of divine spirits and the reverence of humans and ghosts. They will naturally gain vast dwellings, heavenly palaces, and blessed halls, with extraordinary clothing and food, and attendants adorned in splendor.

Matters such as these can be extended to all things, each manifesting in its own way, and need not be exhaustively recorded. The enlightened grasp this: abandoning the existent to seek the non-existent, one need not necessarily attain the non-existent. Attaining the non-existent lies in non-stagnation, and non-stagnation lies in non-attachment. To give when sought is to be without fixation—this is non-stagnation, not abandonment. Though one may not seek, if attachment to possession causes distress, discarding it for others is called abandonment, not non-stagnation. To abandon this for that is to stagnate in the non-existence of this—this is not the Dao. To give when sought, though I do not cling, may bring calamity to the recipient—this is coarse non-stagnation, also not the Dao.

The Dao does not stagnate in subtlety. Subtlety lies in illumination. My abandonment causes no loss, while the recipient gains benefit—this is the Dao, the way of the wise. In giving, there are many ways—what is fitting and what is not. To give fittingly is wisdom; to give unfittingly is folly. Folly lies in giving that contradicts wisdom.

When others come seeking from me, I weigh the truth or falsity of their request. If false, they test me; if true, they rely on me. Those who rely may be good or evil; those who test may be coarse or refined. Coarse tests are to be shattered and destroyed; refined tests are to be declined with courtesy. To decline with courtesy is the way of the sagely teacher.

When good spirits test me with affairs, if I lack wondrous virtue, if my virtue is not yet complete, they come to test me now. With keen perception and clear intent, I already know and understand, free from confusion. Thus, I decline with this—this is wisdom."

chunks.original_text: 摧之者五魔三毒，变化试之，未明吾术，未信吾威，於是治之，诛责制伏，使之归降，能胜魔怨，是名智慧。 被试惊怖，章徨迷惑，是为不度，非智慧人。 非智惠人，陷入魔党，能悟邪群，自拔得出，出邪还正，正心誓志，坚无退转，誉来不喜，毁至不愁，解之有方，消之有法，直置毁誉，无屑中怀，修行正法，道德无懈，毁誉自弭，是智慧也。 彼来加犯，犯不校计，可言言正，不可则已。 嘿识神道，潜捐犯加，加犯自歇，无生报之心，心不怀报，道德日隆。 恶徒恶之，不能中伤，反自受弊，乃更悲之，哀念愚顽，不得逞快，用心若此，是智慧也。 一切凶人，反逆无状，诘道诮德，呵天骂地，毁辱父母，诽谤师君，嫉妬亲友，谗贼善人，有能容忍，受枉不瞋，解喻不已，恭顺不诤，全道在心，是为智慧。 若愤激自明，申直伐枉，损彼利己，或杀身取名，或不顾身，各肆其忿意，死而无悔，或更增感结，非智慧也。 凡一切恶人，凶禽毒兽，虫鸟螫虿，皆应防之，防之无术，术浅不攘，先对既深，今功德浅，报来必至，至不忘道，知是宿罪，所招不怨，今日之苦，念与仇对，解释因缘，不生恶意，强梁加之。 然其初来，轻重未测，先设方法，说喻咒愿，种种释之，务令两不相伤，纵复刀杖恐胁使退，必无杀害，重增怨雠，力设方术，不能却之，分受毁坏，以酬宿对，不起报彼之心，存道求后永免，此为智慧。 凡聪明而贫贱，暗塞而富贵，仁慈而短祚，謟害而长年，无罪而罹祸，有衅而逸游，皆各报对，毫分无差，明通者了，昧滞者疑，疑不能遣，遣不能求，非智慧也。 智慧者无疑，无疑者有识，识三十六天地，明三十六妙行，吟三十六真音，群魔灭爽矣。 三尸极凶，谓为三毒，毒害人命，急宜除之，守一精专，三尸自灭。 一无形象，无欲无为，求之难得，守之易失，失由识暗，不能进明，贪欲滞心，致招衰老，得喜失瞋，致招疾病，迷者不改，致招死殁，殒瞋及老，三尸所延。 治救保全，唯先守一，非一不济，非一不成，守一恬惔，夷心寂求，损欲抑德，反迷入正，廓然无为，与一为一，此为上上之人，先身积极所致也。 中中以上，先善未积，积而未极，皆由渐升，当存三元，谛识神炁，状貌名字，出入有无，主镇三宫，三尸必落，三元又妙，非可即弘，当懃行善，五德备修，万善日积，千魔敢干，尸毒既去，练暗成明，智慧神通，长生不死。 圣真神仙，随因受果，升玄化世，顺运去来，自测测人，观身观物，皆有证验，精详察之，有非即改悔，有是即坚行，斋静存思，服佩药符，章表忏愿，疑实无虚，无贪无欲，不衰不老，老反童婴，身神光泽，无喜无嗔，不病不厄，厄度病除，炁力强盛，无迷无嫉，不死不亡，亡殁不殁，正见无邪，自通通人，与道为一，一合一也，号圣真仙。 欲不能寡，衰不能攘，嗔不能遣，病不能差，愚不能移，死不能免，空称学道，皆虚妄也。 虚妄之徒，终陷魔党，致使世境，有诈称假名，或号太上，或名圣真，矫托神仙，乱惑一切，自非实学，孰能正之。 化邪保正，守一明三，行五备六，六通之人，无有假伪，动静皆真，虽有权化，终用真道。 真道之业，不哀不病，不死长生，教训不倦，古今典籍，过目即谙，照其真伪，了其抑扬，明其漏误，洞其精粗，治定解说，朗然释疑，施经运用，肃然有验，吐言无瑕，出文无累，清谈动天，敷文曜日，落笔成章，序赞玄极，或经或传，或戒或律，或愒或颂，或券或疏，或辞或牒，或章或表，或忏或愿，或诀或符，或记或录，或少或多，或繁或简，或素或华，或文或质，或浅或深，随方设教，行藏不同，出没舛异，隐显之殊。
